de.fhb.sailboat.communication

Interface TransmissionModule

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    CompassReceiver, CompassTransmitter, GPSReceiver, GPSTransmitter, MissionReceiver, MissionTransmitter, RCommTest.FastClientTModule, RCommTest.FastServerTModule, RCommTest.SimpleClientTModule, RCommTest.SimpleServerTModule, WindReceiver, WindTransmitter

    public interface TransmissionModule
    Interface declaring a TransmissionModule. Clases implementing the TransmissionModule are responsible
    for defining a serialization and deserialization algorithm for a certain type of data.
    Transmission modules are to be registered at a CommunicationBase instance.
    Since TransmissionModules on the server and client usually have different tasks to perform,
    there must be created a pair of TransmissionModule classes; one for the client and one for the server.
    If just one TransmissionModule type were to be added at the server and the client, it would result in a cyclic
    ping-pong like transmission, which is usually not intended.
    In order to ensure a successful transmission, all TransmissionModule pairs must be registered at the
    end-nodes (server and client) in the SAME order!!
    Author:
    Michael Kant

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void connectionReset()
      Called by the underlying ModuleWorker, if the connection was closed or interrupted.

    • Method Detail

      • receivedObject

        void receivedObject(java.io.DataInputStream stream)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Called on a registered TransmissionModule, if the related CommunicationBase received a transmission
        that's intended for this TransmissionModule.
        The given TransmissionModule is supposed to decode the data on its own.
        Parameters:
        stream - Stream that provides the data.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - IOException that's back-propagated to the underlying CommunicationBase, if this TransmissionModule doesn't handle the exception itself.

      • skipNextCycle

        boolean skipNextCycle()
        This can be used to get the underlying ModuleWorker to skip the next pending transmission request.
        A useful method for bandwidth optimization.
        Returns:
        True if the next cycle shall be skipped, otherwise false.

      • requestObject

        void requestObject(java.io.DataOutputStream stream)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Called by the underlying ModuleWorker, if the TransmissionModule's transmission interval has been reached and a new object or bunch of data is supposed to be sent.
        The given TransmissionModule is supposed to encode the data on its own.
        Mind, this method is just called if the given transmission interval is greater than 0. (see getTransmissionInterval())
        Parameters:
        stream - Stream that takes the data.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - IOException that's back-propagated to the underlying ModuleWorker, if this TransmissionModule doesn't handle the exception itself.

      • connectionReset

        void connectionReset()
        Called by the underlying ModuleWorker, if the connection was closed or interrupted.

      • getTransmissionInterval

        int getTransmissionInterval()
        Defines the transmission interval of this TransmissionModule.
        The return value is interpreted as milliseconds.
        Setting a transmission interval of 0 or less will cause the TransmissionModule to be declared as passive.
        That means it can just receive incoming objects by receivedObject(DataInputStream) because requestObject(DataOutputStream) is never being called automatically.
        However, requestObject(DataOutputStream) can still be called by explicit request over the communication base.
        Returns:
        The transmission interval value.

      • getPriority

        int getPriority()
        Defines the priority of this TransmissionModule. The higher the priority, the bigger the chance of outgoing data to be preferred on low bandwidth.
        The estimated priority is descending with an ascending priority value. e.g. The highest priority is 1.
        A priority value of 0 or less is however interpreted as no priority at all, which causes given packets to be added to the very end of the priority chain.
        Note: This method is NOT taken into account in the current version of the communication component yet!
        Returns:
        The priority value of the TransmissionModule
